isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Diagnostics Model Years 1999-2000 - ELECTRONIC CONTROL SYSTEM DIAGNOSTICS - Circuit Function And Diagnostics - Engine Crank Inhibit System (ECI)

svcsubproc.title: Signal Function

figure.caption: Function Diagram for Engine Crank Inhibit

svcsubproc.para: The Engine Crank Inhibit function of the ECM controls cranking motor operation. The ECM prevents the cranking motor from being engaged when the engine is running. The transmission neutral safety switch or clutch switch will prevent the cranking motor from being engaged when the transmission is in gear or when the clutch pedal is not depressed.

svcsubproc.title: Electronic Control Module (ECM)
svcsubproc.para: The ECM prevents the engine from being cranked if the engine is running, by not enabeling the Engine Crank Inhibit relay.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Crank Inhibit Relay
svcsubproc.para: The Engine Crank Inhibit relay controls the start relay. The Crank Inhibit relay receives signals from the ignition switch and ECM to close the relay. Current to the relay is supplied from the neutral safety switch on an automatic transmission or clutch pedal switch on a manual transmission.

svcsubproc.title: Start Relay
svcsubproc.para: The start relay sends battery voltage to the crank motor solenoid when the crank inhibit relay is energized. The start relay is protected and controlled by an overcrank thermocouple, if equipped.

svcsubproc.title: Clutch Switch
svcsubproc.para: For vehicles equipped with manual transmissions, the clutch switch supplies power to the Engine Crank Inhibit (ECI) relay and provides a signal to the ECM that indicates the driveline is disengaged. For vehicles programmed for manual transmissions, a 0V signal on the DDS circuit indicates that the clutch is disengaged (clutch pedal down). A 12V signal indicates that the clutch is engaged (clutch pedal up). When the clutch pedal is up no power is available to the ECI relay.

svcsubproc.title: Neutral Switch
svcsubproc.para: For vehicles equipped with mechanical automatic transmissions (Allison AT/MT), the neutral position switch is used to supply power to the ECI relay and provides a signal to the ECM that indicates the driveline is disengaged. For vehicles programmed for Allison AT/MT transmissions, a 12V signal on the DDS circuit indicates that the transmission is out of gear. A 0V signal indicates that the transmission is in gear. When the transmission is in gear no power is available to the ECI relay.

svcsubproc.title: WTEC VIM Relay
svcsubproc.para: For vehicles equipped with the Allison MD World Transmission Electronically Controlled transmission (WTEC), the transmission controller provides a signal to a relay in the VIM module to supply power to the ECI relay and a signal to the ECM to indicate that the driveline is disengaged. For vehicles programmed for Allison MD transmissions, a 12V signal on the DDS circuit indicates that the transmission is out of gear. An 0V signal indicates that the transmission is in gear. When the transmission is in gear no power is available to the ECI relay.

svcsubproc.title: Fault Detection / Management
svcsubproc.para: The ECM does not monitor cranking system circuits. Diagnostic Trouble Codes are not used for this system.

figure.caption: Circuit Diagram for Engine Crank Inhibit

note.para: Before testing Engine Crank Inhibit or cranking circuits, check battery for full charge. Check battery connections at the battery, frame, and starter. See CTS 5000 for battery and starter test procedures.

para.emph: Start Relay Voltage and Resistance Checks - With Starter Relay Removed

entry.para: Check with relay unplugged and starter switch (key or button) engaged. If no voltage is present, troubleshoot clutch or trans switch. ECI circuit or ignition crank circuit.
An open to ground will cause the relay not to energize (check thermal overcrank switch, if equipped).

Crank Circuit Test - With the trans out of gear and the clutch depressed with wheels safely blocked, momentarily insert a jumper wire between socket pins No.30 and No.87 of the Start Relay. NOTE: If the cranking circuit is functional, the starter will energize.
If the engine cranks and voltage is present at 86 and ground at 85 the relay is bad.

para.emph: ECI Relay Voltage and Resistance Checks - With ECI Relay Removed.

entry.para: Check with relay unplugged & starter switch (key or button) engaged. If no voltage present, troubleshoot ignition crank circuit.
If no voltage is present when clutch is depressed or auto. transmission in neutral, troubleshoot clutch switch or neutral safety switch circuit.
ECM will pull circuit up to 4V to 5V with key ON and will go to 0V when the clutch is depressed or transmission is in neutral.

ECI Circuit Test- With the trans out of gear and the clutch depressed with wheels safely blocked, insert a jumper wire between socket pins No.85 and No.87 of the ECI Relay. If the engine cranks, when the start switch is engaged either the ECI relay is bad or there is a problem with the ECM or ECM wiring harness.

para.emph: ECM Chassis (Black) Circuit Checks - Check with All Relays Installed and Breakout Box Connected.

entry.para: Manual Trans - 0V with clutch pedal down, 12V clutch pedal up Automatic Trans - 12V with trans in neutral, 0V trans in gear.
At crank w/clutch up or auto trans in gear, if 12V present ckt good cranking inhibited.
At crank w/clutch down or auto trans in neutral, if ECM pin No.26 is at 12V and pin No.46 is not at 0V to 0.6V, check ECM programming. Cranking allowed.
Pull up voltage from ECM with /key ON, engine OFF or running: trans in gear or clutch up.

svcsubproc.title: Extended Description
svcsubproc.para: The engine starting system is controlled by the Electronic Control Module (ECM). The ECM also prevents cranking motor operation, while the engine is running, that could cause damage to the starter pinion and ring gear.

A clutch switch or transmission neutral switch is in series with the Engine Crank Inhibit relay. Both switches prevent the cranking motor from being engaged unless the transmission is in neutral or the clutch is disengaged.
The Engine Crank Inhibit system includes the following:

item.para: Neutral safety switch (with AT/MT automatic transmission)
VIM relay module (with MD automatic transmission)

svcsubproc.title: System Operation
svcsubproc.para:
See Cranking System Circuit Diagram
for the following description.
When the ignition is turned on and the push button start switch is depressed, current flows to the Engine Crank Inhibit (ECI) relay. The relay is enabled when the ECM supplies the ground circuit.

Closing this relay allows current to pass from the ignition switch through fuse F17 through the neutral safety switch (jumped if manual trans), and through the clutch switch normally closed (jumped if auto trans). With the relay closed current then passes through the relay and will energize the start relay. The ground circuit for the start relay is through the overcrank protection fuse in the crank motor or directly to ground if not equipped with overcrank protection. When the relay is closed the current can pass from the crank motor battery terminal through the relay and to the crank motor solenoid, start terminal. This closes the crank solenoid to engage the starter.

svcsubproc.title: Electronic Control Module (ECM)
svcsubproc.para: When the ECM recognizes that the engine is not running, the ECM will ground terminal 46 providing DDS status is correct. This provides the current path for the Engine Crank Inhibit Relay to close when the Start switch is engaged or the starter button is depressed. When the ECM recognizes that the engine is running the ECM will open terminal 46. This will prevent the Engine Crank Inhibit relay from closing thus preventing the starter motor from engaging.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Crank Inhibit Relay (ECI)
svcsubproc.para: The Engine Crank Inhibit relay controls the current to the start relay. Turning the ignition key to the START, supplies current to the relay at terminal 85. If the engine is not running ECM terminal 46 will enable the relay by supplying a ground circuit to terminal 86. Current for the start relay is supplied through the neutral safety switch if the transmission is in neutral with an automatic transmission to terminal 30. Or if the truck is equipped with a manual transmission, current will be supplied to the relay through the clutch switch if the clutch pedal is depressed. With the relay closed current can pass through the relay to terminal 86 to power the start relay.

svcsubproc.title: Start Relay
svcsubproc.para: The start relay switches battery power to the crank motor solenoid when the crank inhibit relay is energized. When the engine crank inhibit relay is closed, current is supplied to the start relay terminal to energize the relay. The start relay control is grounded through the starter thermal overcrank protection thermocouple if equipped. Or if not, the relay is grounded directly to the ground stud on the starter. With the start relay energized, battery voltage is supplied to the start relay and then switched to the crank motor solenoid to crank the engine.

Before troubleshooting, make certain batteries are fully charged. Voltage readings will not be accurate if the batteries are not fully charged Check battery cables and grounds for clean and tight connections free of damage.

Before troubleshooting, inspect circuit connectors for pushed back, loose or damaged (spread or bent) terminals, or wires with cut strands etc. Wires and connections must be free of damage or corrosion. When some connectors corrode, a light white residue will be present that must be removed.
Before troubleshooting, inspect the suspect circuit ground for clean, tight connections, free of an damage.
